 Talk How to Dual Boot Windows 10 and Ubuntu 16.04   
 There are many benefits to having multiple operating systems available on your computer. This guide will teach you how to install the most current versions of Windows and Ubuntu on a computer that already has Windows 10 installed. Make sure you have an 8GB USB available that you don't mind having wiped. 
 Steps Edit 
 Part One of Four: Getting the Computer Ready for Installation Edit 
 1 
 Back up first, if desired.  If you have any important files that you want to make sure do not get deleted, get a hold of some external storage like an external hard drive and copy all of those files over to the external hard drive. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/8d\/3_windows_10_power_button_settings_0.png\/460px-3_windows_10_power_button_settings_0.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/8d\/3_windows_10_power_button_settings_0.png\/760px-3_windows_10_power_button_settings_0.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":518.30985915493,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":856.33802816901} 
 2 
 Turn off Fast Boot. 
 Open Control Panel (Windows + X -> Control Panel from the desktop in Windows 8+). 
 Navigate to Power Options. 
 Click "Choose what the power button does". 
 Click "Change settings that are currently unavailable". 
 Make sure the box that says "Turn on fast startup (Recommended)" at the bottom is not checked. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/84\/Uefi-firmware.jpg\/460px-Uefi-firmware.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/8\/84\/Uefi-firmware.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":273.37559429477,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":451.66402535658} 
 3 
 Turn off Secure Boot. 
 Press Windows + I to open the settings charms. Click on Change PC settings at the bottom. 
 Go to Update and recovery from left sidebar. Then click Restart now under Advanced startup. 
 Now you will be presented with the "Choose an option" screen. Simply select "Troubleshoot" and then "Advanced options". 
 In the Advanced options menu, choose "UEFI Firmware settings". Then click on the "Restart" button to reboot your system in UEFI settings. 
 Now your PC has been booted into UEFI utility, move to boot on the top menu and here you can see the option to turn off secure boot in Windows 10. Use the arrow key to go to Secure Boot option and then press enter to select it. Use + or – to change its value.

 Part Two of Four: Creating an Ubuntu USB Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d3\/Selection_043.png\/460px-Selection_043.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d3\/Selection_043.png\/760px-Selection_043.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":282.44505494505,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":466.64835164835} 
 1 
 Download Ubuntu ISO.  You will need to download the most recent version of Ubuntu from the official website.
 Navigate to  http://www.ubuntu.com/download/desktop 
 Download the most recent version of Ubuntu. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/ec\/Download-desktop-usb-windows-7.jpg\/459px-Download-desktop-usb-windows-7.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/ec\/Download-desktop-usb-windows-7.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":515.2,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":851.2} 
 2 
 Download Rufus.  Rufus is a free program to create a Live USB, which you will need to install Ubuntu.
 Open your internet browser and navigate to  https://rufus.akeo.ie/ 
 Download and install the newest version of the rufus.exe 
 3 
 Create a bootable USB. 
 Open Rufus and select your USB stick in the 'Device' dropdown. 
 Click the CD Rom icon next to the 'FreeDOS' dropdown. Then find your downloaded Ubuntu ISO and click 'Open' and then 'Start'. 
 Click 'Yes' when it asks to download the Syslinux software. 
 Click 'OK' to write in ISO Image mode. 
 Confirm that your USB stick is selected and then 'OK' to continue. 
 4 When it is finished, just restart your computer and start using Ubuntu, or you can install Ubuntu. 
 Advertisement 
 Part Three of Four: Creating a Partition Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c5\/Image00.png\/460px-Image00.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c5\/Image00.png\/760px-Image00.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":308.35164835165,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":509.45054945055} 
 1 
 Place the Ubuntu USB that you made into your computer and boot from the USB.  When give the option choose to "Try Ubuntu". You are now running the ubuntu off the USB, but you will want to continue to install it on your computer.
 2 
 Tap the Windows key on your keyboard and search for a program called gParted.  Then click the gParted icon to begin running the program. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d3\/Dual-boot-windows-8-ubuntu-create-new-root.png\/460px-Dual-boot-windows-8-ubuntu-create-new-root.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/d3\/Dual-boot-windows-8-ubuntu-create-new-root.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":231.16751269036,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":381.92893401015} 
 3 
 Select your Windows partition, which will likely be the largest partition on the drive.  Click the orange right facing arrow icon. Shrink the partition by at least 25GB so that it has free space after it.
 Advertisement 
 Part Four of Four: Installing Ubuntu Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b6\/Try-ubuntu-16-04.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b6\/Try-ubuntu-16-04.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":298.48888888889,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":493.15555555556} 
 1 
 Click the "Install Ubuntu 16.04 LTS" on the desktop.  This will start the installation wizard for Ubuntu.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e6\/Install-Ubuntu-Wizard-step-2.png\/460px-Install-Ubuntu-Wizard-step-2.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e6\/Install-Ubuntu-Wizard-step-2.png\/760px-Install-Ubuntu-Wizard-step-2.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":270.43956043956,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":446.81318681319} 
 2 
 You may choose to click these check boxes.  They are optional and should not affect you installation.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b8\/Image03.png\/460px-Image03.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b8\/Image03.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":340.57692307692,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":562.69230769231} 
 3 
 Choose the "Something else" option and click continue. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/da\/LjMlH.png\/460px-LjMlH.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/da\/LjMlH.png\/759px-LjMlH.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":210.41208791209,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":347.63736263736} 
 4 
 Click the + icon.  This will open a new window where you can choose to add partitions.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0e\/C8yln.png\/460px-C8yln.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0e\/C8yln.png\/759px-C8yln.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":210.41208791209,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":347.63736263736} 
 5 
 Create a root partition.  Decrease the size of this partition so you have enough room to spare enough size for you swap partition. Use as: should be Ext4 journaling file system. The Mount point: should be set to / from the drop down menu and click OK.
 6 
 Create a Swap Partition.  Set the size to be at least 4GB (4096MB). Change Use as: to swap partition and click OK. Click Install Now to continue. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b2\/Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_6.jpg\/459px-Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_6.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b2\/Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_6.jpg\/759px-Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":271.7032967033,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":448.9010989011} 
 7 
 Select your Location and click Continue. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/29\/Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_7.jpg\/459px-Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_7.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/29\/Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_7.jpg\/759px-Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_7.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":269.80769230769,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":445.76923076923} 
 8 
 Select your keyboard layout and click Continue. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e6\/Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_8.jpg\/460px-Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_8.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e6\/Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_8.jpg\/760px-Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_8.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":272.33516483516,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":449.94505494505} 
 9 
 Enter your Login and Password details and Click continue. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a1\/Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_9.jpg\/459px-Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_9.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a1\/Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_9.jpg\/760px-Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_9.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":347.52747252747,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":574.17582417582} 
 10 
 Wait for the installation to finish. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/74\/Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_10.jpg\/460px-Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_10.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/74\/Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_10.jpg\/760px-Download-desktop-install-ubuntu-desktop_10.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":118.79120879121,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":196.26373626374} 
 11 
 When your installation is complete restart your computer.

 After this, can I use Windows 10? 
								Answered by  
								 Orion Zewde   
 Yes. Windows 10 should be accessible through the GRUB2 menu (it's the first screen that greets you when you turn on your PC). Also make sure you installed both Ubuntu and Windows in UEFI mode or both in BIOS, because if they are different it will be difficult booting from one to the other.

 Tips Edit 
 If you run into trouble, try a grub2 repair
 Open up the terminal and these two commands:  sudo add-apt-repository ppa:yannubuntu/boot-repair && sudo apt-get update  and  sudo apt-get install -y boot-repair && boot-repair 
 If successful then you should see the boot repair window. 
 Click recommended repair and follow the steps.
